title: 107_hr5404
content: The "Social Security Fairness Act of 2002" is cited as the short title. It amends the Social Security Act to include a new subsection regarding the termination of the last monthly insurance benefit payment upon death. The "Social Security Fairness Act of 2002" introduces changes to the Social Security Act related to the termination of insurance benefits upon an individual's death. It specifies that if an individual dies within the first 15 days of a month, their monthly benefit will be 50% of the original amount, rounded up to the nearest dollar. This adjustment applies after all other benefit adjustments have been made. Additionally, payments for the month of death will follow specific guidelines outlined in section 204(d) of the Act. Section 202(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to increase the applicable dollar amount for lump-sum death payments to $955 for any calendar year, with adjustments made by the Commissioner of Social Security after 2002. The applicable dollar amount for any calendar year is $955, with adjustments made by the Commissioner of Social Security after 2002 based on the national average wage index. The national average wage index for calendar year 2001 is used to determine certain dollar amounts, which are rounded to the nearest multiple of $5.00 if necessary. The amendments made by this Act will apply to deaths occurring after 90 days from the enactment date.
